Take a very basic statistics class and you will understand that factors contributing to the variability you describe can be understood and adjustments can be made accordingly.

This of course is one of those things that seem to be a no brainer but when you step back, you see how difficult it is. I'll give you an example. A company has 2 widget factories. One has a rejection rate of 18%; the other 4%. Obviously the second factory is doing a much better job. So an efficiency expert is sent in. He discovers the water at the first factory is much more impure than the second. And she finds, that given the raw materials of the first, it is really doing a much better job. Impossible? Of course not.

Lee might be the single greatest figure in undermining American labor movement.

According to "The Miracle" by Michael Schuman shortly after Singapore's separation from Malaysia he attended a conference in the US filled with executive's from US companies. There he learned to his surprise that US executives would like to build factories off shore. All Lee had to do was minimize the transaction cost for doing so. That he did.

He built modern industrial parks and provided a disciplined English speaking labor force. Lee tried to make Singapore so American like that an exec would forget he's in a foreign country, except in one aspect: the executive was catered pampered and treated like the Masters of the Universe they think themselves to be. An American exec in Singapore would feel he had arrived in Nirvana. The plan was a success.

This began in the mid60s when the population of Singapore was only 2.5 million. Within about a decade or so Singapore had been industrialized and began to move into higher value services in finance and transportation. Meanwhile neighboring countries adopted Lee's plan allowing Singapore to play the role of hub in the region. When Deng asked Lee for advice on how to move China forward quickly Lee recommended his outsourcing plan.

The crucial aspect was Am Execs desire to destroy American labor by going offshore. Something Lee thought unpatriotic (he was trying to raise compatriot's income while they were doing the opposite) but was quick to exploit.

"Iceland repudiated its debts, while Greece hasn't. Why?"

Greece's adoption of the euro, while Iceland kept the krone, is a major factor. This would make Greek repudiation extra messy, but the key factor is this: Greece is looking at sovereign debt, while Iceland's was all about the banks, which were leveraged to integer multiples of Iceland's GDP. So Iceland let the banks fail and used its fiscal capabilities to bail out its people.

And some bankers went to jail!

Dear Professor Krugman: You've asked the right question. Here are some circumstances which, I think, explains why Mercer County and Iceland does not have its own currency, doesn't need its own currency, and benefits from being part of the dollar currency union, while Iceland does. To save time, I incorporate herein, as if fully set forth herein, the Mundell-Fleming conditions for an optimal currency area: (1) Labor mobility across the area; (2) Capital mobility and price and wage flexibility across the area; (3) A risk sharing system in the form of a fiscal transfer mechanism for the entire area; and (4) Homogeneity of business cycles across the area. Mercer County has all four of the foregoing in the dollar currency area, the United States, while in the Eurozone at least 3 and 4, supra, are lacking, which means that the Eurozone can't adjust to equilibrim for some members advantages in competitiveness and the resulting imbalances in trade, except by internal devaluation, nor can it aid members which are experiencing a fiscal crisis.

But Professor Kenen provides perhaps the most insightful analysis of why the dollar area works, while the Eurozone doesn't. Kenen supplements Mundell-Fleming to include: (1) Production diversification; (2) Homogeneous Preferences; and, most importantly, (3) Commonality of destiny. The Eurozone lacks all three of Kenen's conditions, but it particularly lacks the third, the commonality of destiny, (cont.)

Two groups seek to recruit Afghanistan. India wants to use it against Pakistan, and Pakistan wants to use it against India.

This article uses the Indian point of view, without explanation or examination. The strategic depth and militancy it derides are the key concepts of Pakistan's defense against India, specifically regarding Kashmir.

Afghanistan will cease to be pulled between these two only if they finally settle the Kashmir question, and make a larger peace. Until then, both sides will look at the strategic depth of the other around the contested region, and Pakistan will use militancy to resist the occupation of Kashmir.

As between these two, Afghanistan is as much an object used for other purposes as it always was to the US against first the Soviets and then Iran and China.

Incidentally, the US is still trying to use Afghanistan against Iran and China, and they are mentioned in this article as siding with Pakistan, again without explanation or context.

Settle Kashmir. Settle the US/Iran controversy. Stop trying to set up bases in the backcountry of Afghanistan in some dream they could be of use against China. Then the Taliban on both sides will have nothing more to be proxy for, and the fighting will die off.

which can be translated as a sense of national identity.

In other words, there are no Eurozonians, as there are Americans in the United States, which means that the sense of solidarity, which makes a nation, is absent. And that is fatal, because it is that nationhood, which gives rise to all of the other necessary conditions in the Mundell-Fleming-Kenen model. The other necessary conditions of the Mundell-Fleming-Kenen model are simply emergent properties of nationhood.

Mercer County is part of a nation, the United States, from which all the other necessary conditions of an optimal currency area emerge, while the 19 members of the Eurozone are not one nation. Iceland recognized that fact and wisely kept its own currency, while the 19 members of the Eurozone are at best a collection of factions, which have contradictory interests and, thus, can't satisfy the Mundell-Fleming-Kenen conditions for a viable currency area.

Prof. Krugman is the expert on inter-regional trade both inside and outside of a currency area and the extent to which such trade or the lack of it motivates a single currency, as opposed to multiple currencies, so I'll defer to him. However, the numbers seem to indicate that at least several large economies in the Eurozone engage in significant inter-zone trade. The evidence is that the rich core nations enjoy riches from their advantages in competitiveness, which would not be the case if there was not significant trade.

However, your second point is quite interesting. That Iceland's currency provides for an automatic adjustment mechanism to rebalance trade, whereby a fall in the currency reduces imports and increases substitute domestic production. Poor regions of the U.S. don't have their own currency, but fiscal transfer mechanisms, e.g., social security, welfare payments, etc., which are supposed to be the adjustment mechanisms that revives depressed areas.

Are the U.S. transfer mechanisms inadequate? Yes, they are, but notwithstanding, Mississippi et al. would not, I think, be better off with their own currencies. My reasons are these: First, as one of our interlocutors notes, the U.S. tried that in the past, with each state issuing its own currency. That experiment was such a disaster that it led to the Federal Reserve system and the dollar; our poor regions lack the endowment and other assets to be wealthy on their own and, thus, benefit from the dollar.

Consider how economic output is traded. Most services are produced in a specific location, and consumers have to go to that location to get them. For example, if you want health care, you go to a hospital. Within a city, people can move around on the freeway network, so a lot of trade in services is possible.

Things like manufactured goods and agricultural products are different because they can be moved to the consumer's location. This makes it practical to trade them on a global scale, although transportation costs may outweigh the benefit. Where transportation costs are already high, the additional hassle of dealing in two currencies may not be that important.

For a city which is part of the New York metro area, a separate currency would have huge costs, because of the huge amount of trade within the region. That is not true for a remote economy like Iceland, where most of the trade is in manufactured goods.

The huge advantage of a separate currency for Iceland is that it provides a way to balance trade if a large exporter shuts down. A falling currency will push the rest of the economy towards self-sufficiency, which will create local jobs. On the other hand, if a new exporter moves in , the economy will make greater use of imported goods.

US regions lack this adjustment mechanism, so they often end up chronically depressed if their old industry leaves. This is not so likely if the workforce can commute to new jobs.

Thank you to Mrs. Evans for sharing this candid account of her feelings about losing the life she hoped to have with her daughter. I wish we could raise questions and discuss different perspectives in the comments without actively insulting the religious tradition in which Mrs. Evans and her husband chose to raise their daughter Barbara, now Sister Mary Joseph. I also think it might be worthwhile to consider that many people the same age as Sister Mary Joseph, in the early throes of a pursuit about which they are passionate, interpret the standards of that pursuit with particular zeal. Certainly the Handmaids are a very traditional and restrictive community, but it's also possible that with time, Sister Mary Joseph will discover there is a little more flexibility than she's feeling at the moment. If not, I gather from this post that her mother will support her, nonetheless, and celebrate the life she has chosen. In either event, rich blessings to them and to those with whom they share their lives. Know, however, Mrs. Evans, that you will always be Barbara's mother

Argentina has its own currency and that didn't help Argentina from repeatedly defaulting.

Iceland's default was a one time thing. Icelanders used to make livings on fishing (more or less). Then for one reason or another, Icelanders briefly caught the Wall St. bug and decided to play bankers. That didn't end well. Then they wrote off the debt and decided to go back to fishing. The bond market cares about the past behavior only in the context of future risks. Since the Icelanders have repented and gone back to fishing, interest rate falls, more or less.

Argentina and Greece can't collect taxes. Moreover, their govs spend like drunken sailors and borrow to defaults. Argentina has its own currency and devaluates and then pegs to USD then comes off of USD peg. None of this made Argentina economy. As far as the bond market is concerned, Argentina gov still can't collect taxes.

Greece did pretty much the same as Argentina. It can't print money, but it can still default. As far as the bond market is concerned, Greek gov still can't collect taxes.

Oh by the way, Icelandic gov can collect taxes.
